[Combat Module] [Tank War] Shooting Logic 

THIẾT KẾ LOGIC BẮN (2.5D-aware, Unity Kinematic)

Version: 1.1 

Người viết: O Kent (QuocTA) 

Ngày cập nhật: 17 - 09 - 2025 

1. Mục lục 

2. Mục tiêu & Phạm vi 

1.1 Mục tiêu UX   
1.2 Phạm vi   
1.3 Vấn đề hiện tại 

3. Nguyên tắc thiết kế 

4. Thuật ngữ & Định nghĩa 

5. Tổng quan kiến trúc hệ thống 

5.1 Lớp A — 2.5D Collision Band (MẶC ĐỊNH ON)   
5.2 Lớp B — Multi-Height Sweep (OPTIONAL)   
5.3 Lớp C — Smart Pitch Assist (OPTIONAL) 

6. Yêu cầu (Request) 6.1 Yêu cầu chức năng (FR) 6.2 Yêu cầu phi chức năng (NFR) 

7. Cấu hình dữ liệu (không code) 7.1 BulletProfile (đề xuất trường) 7.2 ClassProfile (band preset theo class) 7.3 Blocker Category (cho Level/Art/Dev cấu hình) 

8. Quy trình bắn (Flow — không code) 

2. Mục tiêu & Phạm vi 

1.1 Mục tiêu UX 

Đạn không “lướt qua” vật cản thấp khi người chơi kỳ vọng bị chặn. Giữ đạn kinematic (không dùng Rigidbody/forces) để dễ kiểm soát & nhẹ CPU. ▪ Tăng tính “công bằng trực quan” trong bắn ngang (mặt phẳng XZ) nhưng vẫn tôn trọng chênh lệch cao độ (Y). ▪ Cấu hình linh hoạt theo tank class, bản đồ, mode. 

1.2 Phạm vi 

▪ Áp dụng cho đạn thẳng (hitscan-like kinematic projectile) của mọi class. Không bao gồm tên lửa đạn đạo/đạn cong/đạn bám mục tiêu (sẽ có GDD riêng). 

1.3 Vấn đề hiện tại 

▪ Vì muzzle (nòng súng) cao, đạn bay thẳng ở cao độ Y cố định vật cản thấp (thùng, tường lửng, lan can) bị lướt qua đỉnh $ \mathsf { U X }$ cảm giác “đạn xuyên vật cản”. 

3. Nguyên tắc thiết kế 

◦ 2.5D trước, 3D sau: Quyết định va chạm ưu tiên theo mặt phẳng XZ (nhận thức của người chơi), sau đó kiểm tra chồng lấn theo Y để xác thực.   
◦ Tha lỗi có kiểm soát: Cho phép yForgiveness nhỏ để giảm các trường hợp “suýt trúng”.   
◦ Data-driven: Toàn bộ tham số có thể cấu hình per-class, per-mode.   
◦ Hiệu năng: Tối đa 1 sphere/capsule cast mỗi frame/đạn $[ \mathsf { m a c }$ định); các sweep bổ sung có thể bật/tắt theo map.   
◦ Khả dụng đa bộ phận: Dev đọc implement; Art đọc sản xuất VFX/SFX/UI; Level Design đọc quy ước chiều cao; QA đọc test. 

4. Thuật ngữ & Định nghĩa 

◦ Muzzle: điểm phát bắn trên nòng súng.   
◦ Attack Band (Y-band của đạn): khoảng cao độ mà đạn được phép coi là chạm va chạm. Xác định bởi [y − bandDown, y $^ +$ bandUp] .   
◦ Hit Band (Y-band của vật cản): khoảng cao độ “thân” của vật cản/đối tượng được tính va chạm, lấy từ collider.bounds và HitBandPad.   
◦ yForgiveness: biên độ “tha lỗi” khi hai band gần chạm nhau. Multi-Height Sweep: bó ray/cast song song tại nhiều cao độ mẫu từ mặt đất đến gần muzzle để phát hiện vật cản thấp ở gần.   
◦ Smart Pitch Assist: dịch nhẹ góc pitch của hướng bắn $( \pm 1 ^ { \circ } { \sim } 3 ^ { \circ } )$ trước khi spawn đạn để giảm các tình huống hụt vô lý. 

◦ Blocker Category: phân loại vật cản (Wall_Low/Wall_High/Fence_Thin/Vehicle/Shield/Vegetation). 

5. Tổng quan kiến trúc hệ thống 

Hệ thống gồm 3 lớp; có thể bật/tắt độc lập theo mode/map: 

5.1 Lớp A — 2.5D Collision Band (MẶC ĐỊNH ON) 

▪ Đạn di chuyển kinematic; mỗi frame thực hiện Sphere/Capsule Cast theo hướng bắn nếu trúng collider, kiểm tra overlap Y-band giữa Attack Band (đạn) và Hit Band (đối tượng).   
▪ Nếu overlap (kể cả trong ngưỡng yForgiveness) tính là HIT.   
▪ Nếu không overlap bỏ qua va chạm (tiếp tục bay). 

5.2 Lớp B — Multi-Height Sweep (OPTIONAL) 

▪ Khi bóp cò, thực hiện thêm 2‒3 sweep tại các cao độ mẫu ( groundY+0.3, $^ { + } \Theta . \odot , ^ { \phantom {

chunk-bd0e1bfe4b189f19fafa9def3fc41bb1.content:
▪ Nếu overlap (kể cả trong ngưỡng yForgiveness) tính là HIT.   
▪ Nếu không overlap bỏ qua va chạm (tiếp tục bay). 

5.2 Lớp B — Multi-Height Sweep (OPTIONAL) 

▪ Khi bóp cò, thực hiện thêm 2‒3 sweep tại các cao độ mẫu ( groundY+0.3, $^ { + } \Theta . \odot , ^ { \phantom { + } } + \Theta . \odot \phantom { | } \mathsf { m } )$ .   
▪ Nếu bất kỳ sweep nào báo va chạm sớm hơn đường thẳng từ muzzle ưu tiên vị trí đó để chặn đạn.   
▪ Dùng khi map có nhiều vật cản lùn/khe hở. 

5.3 Lớp C — Smart Pitch Assist (OPTIONAL) 

▪ Trước khi spawn đạn, điều chỉnh nhẹ pitch trong phạm vi $\pm 3 ^ { \circ }$ để “ghé xuống” nếu trước mặt có blocker thấp. Không phải auto-aim; chỉ giảm case “bay sượt đỉnh” khó chịu. 

[Inference] Multiplayer có thể cần xử lý hit server-authoritative. Khi đó, logic 3 lớp cần phản chiếu tương đương ở server hoặc dùng seed/lockstep để tránh lệch. 

6. Yêu cầu (Request) 

6.1 Yêu cầu chức năng (FR) 

◦ FR-1: Đạn bị block khi đường bay giao XZ với collider thuộc Blocker Category và Attack Band overlap Hit Band của đối tượng. 

◦ FR-2: yForgiveness áp dụng cả hai phía (đạn & vật cản).   
FR-3: Cho phép bật/tắt Multi-Height Sweep và Pitch Assist theo map/mode.   
◦ FR-4: Cho phép preset per-class (Scout/Assault/Heavy) cho bandUp/bandDown.   
◦ FR-5: Tôn trọng team filtering (không hit đồng đội nếu thiết kế yêu cầu).   
◦ FR-6: End-of-Range: đạn nổ/biến mất khi đạt range tối đa, có VFX khác biệt so với hit.   
◦ FR-7: Bề mặt khác nhau tạo VFX vật liệu khác nhau (kim loại/đất/đá/wood/shield). 

6.2 Yêu cầu phi chức năng (NFR) 

◦ NFR-Perf: Mặc định $\leqslant 1$ shape cast/frame/bullet (Lớp A). Nếu bật Lớp B, tổng $\leqslant 3$ cast thêm ở khởi phát.   
◦ NFR-Data: Mọi tham số có thể chỉnh via ScriptableObject (BulletProfile, ClassProfile, MapProfile).   
◦ NFR-UX: Tỷ lệ “khi người chơi nghĩ trúng mà game báo hụt” phải $< 5 \%$ trong playtes   
◦ NFR-QA: Có ma trận test kèm tiêu chí pass/fail. 

7. Cấu hình dữ liệu (không code) 

7.1 BulletProfile (đề xuất trường) 

7.2 ClassProfile (band preset theo class) 

Toàn bộ con số là [Baseline] để playtest/tuning. 

Vegetation mặc định không block (trừ khi có thiết kế đặc biệt). 

8. Quy trình bắn (Flow — không code) 

Pre-Fire 

◦ Lấy ClassProfile set bandUp/bandDown.   
◦ (Nếu bật) Smart Pitch Assist : đánh giá blocker thấp trong 2‒6m trước mặt áp pitch offset $\leqslant$ PitchAssistMaxDeg .   
◦ (Nếu bật) Multi‑Height Sweep : cast tại SweepHeights (theo groundY). Nếu phát hiện hit sớm hơn đường thẳng từ muzzle lưu HitCandidate. 

Flight 

◦ Mỗi frame: Sphere/Capsule Cast theo hướng bay trong khoảng Speed \* Δt .   
◦ Nếu trúng collider thuộc HitMask tính overlap Y-band (Attack vs Hit).   
◦ Nếu overlap (kể cả trong YForgiveness ) HIT (ưu tiên HitCandidate nếu có).   
◦ Nếu không có hit & đã bay hết $\mathsf { R a n g e } \mid \to$ End-of-Range. 

Impact 

◦ Tạo VFX vật liệu, SFX, decal (nếu bề mặt cho phép); gửi sự kiện damage; sinh camera shake nhỏ (xem mục 9).   
◦ Ghi Telemetry (xem mục 9). 

9. Tương tác & Quy tắc đặc biệt 

Đồng đội: mặc định không block (friendly-fire off). Nếu bật friendly-block, thêm Outline/UI cảnh báo. ◦ Shield: luôn block, hiển thị impact FX energy đặc trưng; xuyên shield cần đạn/skill đặc biệt. ◦ Vật thể rất mỏng (cọc/thanh): ưu tiên CapsuleCast hoặc tăng Radius ở bullet nhanh. ◦ Mặt dốc/ramps: Multi-Height Sweep tính groundY tại XZ để không sai lệch. ◦ Tốc độ đạn rất cao: giữ shape cast (không dùng ray đơn) để tránh tunneling. 

10. Art / VFX / SFX / UI (Asset Bible rút gọn) 

10.1 VFX 

▪ Hit Blocker (vật liệu): 3‒5 preset theo vật liệu (đá/kim loại/gỗ/đất/năng lượng).   
▪ Hit Shield: flare năng lượng $^

chunk-25d8e58824865274f259ef4b1be66e33.content:
không sai lệch. ◦ Tốc độ đạn rất cao: giữ shape cast (không dùng ray đơn) để tránh tunneling. 

10. Art / VFX / SFX / UI (Asset Bible rút gọn) 

10.1 VFX 

▪ Hit Blocker (vật liệu): 3‒5 preset theo vật liệu (đá/kim loại/gỗ/đất/năng lượng).   
▪ Hit Shield: flare năng lượng $^ +$ ripple. End-of-Range: pop nhẹ, khác biệt với Hit Blocker. Tracer: chiều cao bám đường đạn; có thể khóa Y theo bullet để nhất quán.   
▪ Debris: bụi/đá vụn/tia lửa nhỏ; scale theo tốc độ va chạm. 

10.2 SFX 

▪ Impact theo vật liệu; Shield riêng.   
▪ End-of-Range: âm “tắt” nhẹ, không nhầm với trúng mục tiêu.   
▪ Ducking ngắn khi hit gần camera. 

10.3 UI/Camera Feedback 

Crosshair State: • Idle, Firing, Blocked-Soon (nếu Sweep báo blocker $8 2 - 3 m$ trước mặt viền crosshair mờ cảnh báo 150ms). 

▪ Camera Shake: • Hit Blocker: 0.15‒0.2 amplitude, 0.1s. 

• Hit Shield: 0.1 amplitude, 0.12s. 

• End-of-Range: không rung. 

▪ Aim Assist Indicator (nếu Pitch Assist on): icon mờ 100ms để truyền thông minh bạch. 

10.4 Yêu cầu Naming & Foldering 

VFX/Bullet/Hit_Metal , VFX/Bullet/Hit_Stone ,   
VFX/Bullet/Hit_Shield   
SFX/Bullet/Impact_Metal   
UI/Crosshair/\* 

11. Level Design Guideline (Chiều cao & Tags) 

◦ Quy ước đơn vị: 1 Unity unit $= 1 \mathsf { m }$ . 

◦ Dải chiều cao khuyến nghị: 

▪ Blocker thấp: $0 . 7 \mathrm { - } 1 . 1 \mathrm { m }  \mathrm { t a g }$ Wall_Low . ▪ Blocker cao: $> 1 . 2 \ : \mathsf { m }  \mathrm { t a g }$ Wall_High Lan can/hàng rào mỏng: $0 . 9 \mathrm { - } 1 . 2 \mathrm { m } \mathrm {  } \mathrm { t a g }$ Fence_Thin 

◦ Collider: ưu tiên Box/Convex Mesh, tránh concave phức tạp. 

◦ HitBandPad: theo bảng 7.3; có thể override ở prefab. 

◦ Vegetation: $\mathsf { m a c }$ định không block (trừ prefab đặc biệt có tag Blocker ) 

◦ Scene Test: mỗi map cần khu test gồm: tường 0.8/1.0/1.2m, lan can mỏng, dốc $1 5 ^ { \circ }$ , bồn cây. 

12. QA — Ma trận Test & Tiêu chí Pass 

Telemetry đối chiếu: ghi PerceivedHitMismatch (người chơi ngắm blocker nhưng game cho xuyên) mục tiêu $< 5 \%$ . 

13. Telemetry & Tuning 

Sự kiện 

◦ Bullet.Fire {class, map, pitchAssistUsed}   
◦ Bullet.HitBlocker {blockerCategory, distance, normalY, bandOverlapDelta}   
◦ Bullet.EndOfRange {distance}   
◦ UX.PerceivedHitMismatch {context} (đánh dấu khi người chơi ngắm XZ trúng blocker nhung khong hit; thu thäp qua debug tool/QA) 

Dashboard đề xuất 

◦ Tỉ lệ HitBlocker theo blockerCategory & class.   
◦ Phân bố bandOverlapDelta để điều chỉnh YForgiveness .   
◦ Tỉ lệ pitchAssistUsed theo map cân nhắc bật/tắt mặc định. 

14. Rủi ro & Kế hoạch triển khai 

◦ Rủi ro: Over-assist cảm giác “dính ảo”. Mitigation: Giới hạn PitchAssistMaxDeg ≤ 3° ; review clip QA.   
◦ Rủi ro: Hiệu năng giảm khi bật Sweep toàn map. Mitigation: Chỉ bật ở map nhiều blocker thấp; cache groundY.   
◦ Triển khai từng bước: ▪ Lớp A (mặc định) $ 2$ ) Lớp B (map-specific) $ 3$ ) Lớp C (A/B test). 

◦ Fallback: Cho phép tắt Lớp B/C bằng config runtime. 

15. Tích hợp hệ thống liên quan 

◦ Damage & Combat Log: sự kiện OnBulletHit gọi damage, ghi Combat Score.   
◦ VFX Tiers (3/6/9/10): kế thừa hiệu ứng theo ATK/FireRate; Hit FX material tách riêng.   
◦ Audio Mix: route Impact bus SFX_Impact; Shield SFX_Energy.   
◦ UI: Crosshair state $^ +$ icon PitchAssist (nếu bật) 100‒150 ms. 

16. Phụ lục 

16.1 Layer & Tag (đề xuất) 

Layers: Obstacle_Blocker , Unit_Tank , Shield , Vegetation , Projectile .   
Tags: Wall_Low , Wall_H

FX material tách riêng.   
◦ Audio Mix: route Impact bus SFX_Impact; Shield SFX_Energy.   
◦ UI: Crosshair state $^ +$ icon PitchAssist (nếu bật) 100‒150 ms. 

16. Phụ lục 

16.1 Layer & Tag (đề xuất) 

Layers: Obstacle_Blocker , Unit_Tank , Shield , Vegetation , Projectile .   
Tags: Wall_Low , Wall_High , Fence_Thin , Vehicle , Shield , NonBlock_Vegetation . 

16.2 Tham số gợi ý theo mode 

16.3 Glossary 

2.5D: logic ưu tiên XZ, kiểm chứng Y.   
Band: khoảng chiều cao chấp nhận va chạm.   
Sweep: loạt kiểm tra song song ở nhiều cao độ.

Key data points include: - **Speed**: A float representing bullet velocity at 40 m/s, which aligns with performance requirements (NFR-Perf) to ensure efficient computation per frame. - **Range**: Defined as weapon-dependent, emphasizing customization based on armament. - **Radius**: A small cast radius of 0.1m ensures precision while maintaining computational efficiency. - **BandUp/Down and YForgiveness**: These define vertical hit tolerance bands (0.5m upward, 0.8m downward, with a forgiveness margin of 0.15m), supporting FR-2 by accounting for both bullet and obstacle forgiveness. - **UseMultiHeightSweep**: A boolean flag indicating map-dependent activation, directly linked to FR-3's requirement for flexible multi-height sweep functionality. - **SweepHeights**: Specifies heights [0.3, 0.6, 0.9] meters for multi-height casts if enabled, enhancing accuracy in detecting obstacles or targets. - **UsePitchAssist** and **PitchAssistMaxDeg**: Pitch assist is off by default but can adjust pitch up to 3 degrees when activated, addressing FR-4 for class-specific presets. - **HitMask**: Layer definitions for blockers/targets are project-specific, ensuring proper team filtering per FR-5. Statistical insights reveal that most numeric values are tightly constrained, reflecting optimization for gameplay balance and performance. Relationships between fields like BandUp/BandDown and YForgiveness highlight the system’s robust handling of vertical collision detection. Similarly, UseMultiHeightSweep and SweepHeights demonstrate an adaptive approach to environmental interactions. In relation to the surrounding content, this table supports functional requirements (FRs) and non-functional requirements (NFRs). For instance, it adheres to NFR-Perf through efficient shape casting limits and respects NFR-UX by minimizing false negatives via precise hit tolerances. Additionally, the configurability via ScriptableObject aligns with NFR-Data, enabling dynamic adjustments during playtesting.

chunk-0ada5276da6c9d0ca153a30e6453339b.content:
[Game Mode Module] [Tank War] Deathmatch 

THIẾT KẾ GAMEMODE DEATHMATCH 

Version: 1.2 

Người viết: phucth12 (phucth12) 

Ngày tạo: 09 - 09 - 2025 

1.1 Tổng quan thiết kế 

Death Mode là chế độ PvP nơi 10 người chơi tham gia vào một trận chiến ngắn kéo dài 4 phút 

• Mỗi người điều khiển một Tank riêng và chiến đấu solo 

• Trong thời gian giới hạn, người chơi phải tiêu diệt càng nhiều đối thủ càng tốt, và quyết định thắng thua dựa trên người có số Kill cao nhất 

• Death Mode giữ nguyên hệ thống nâng cấp chỉ số trong trận tương tự với mode Base Capture 

1.2 Mục tiêu thiết kế 

• Tạo ra một chế độ chơi cạnh tranh giải trí và không mang tính chiến thuật 

• Đem đến trải nghiệm “pick up & play” trong 3 phút, dễ dàng cho người chơi quay lại. 

• Cung cấp mode giải trí nhưng vẫn mang tính ranking để so sánh thành tích. 

2. UserFlow 

3. Chi tiết thiết kế 

3.1 Core Rules 

3.2 Cơ chế chơi 

1. Matchmaking 

◦ Số người chơi: 6 người/trận. 

◦ Hình thức ghép: Solo Free-for-All (không chia team). 

◦ Quy tắc ghép: Sử dụng quy tắc match making được define tại: [Multiplayer Module] [Tank War] Matchmaking System Design 

2. Quy tắc Spawn & Respawn 

2.1 Spawn đầu trận 

Số lượng spawn point: 6 điểm được thiết kế sẵn trong map tương ứng với 6 người chơi 

◦ Nguyên tắc chọn điểm spawn: 

▪ Mỗi người chơi sapwn random tại vị trí bất kỳ trên map, tránh các vị trí có obstacles (nước, bụi cỏ, bùn lầy,...) 

2.2 Respawn sau khi chết 

◦ Thời gian respawn: 3 giây (đếm ngược trên HUD). 

◦ Hiệu ứng bất tử: Ngay sau khi respawn, người chơi có 2s nhận được hiệu ứng bất tử. Trong 2s này người chơi sẽ nhận được shield bảo vệ bản thân khỏi mọi loại sát thương. Hết 2s Shield biến mất 

◦ Điểm Respawn: Random tại vị trí bất kỳ trên map, tránh các vị trí có obstacles (cỏ/đầm lầy/nước) 

3. Cơ chế nâng cấp Tank In-Match 

Sử dụng cơ chế nâng cấp Tank giống như mode chơi Capture Base: [Combat Module] [Tank War] Hệ Thống Nâng Cấp Tank In-Match 

4. Cơ chế Thắng ‒ Thua & Xếp hạng 

A. Nguyên tắc chung: 

• Điều kiện thắng: Khi kết thúc 3 phút, người chơi có số Kill cao nhất sẽ thắng. 

• Bảng xếp hạng: Toàn bộ 6 người chơi được xếp hạng từ $1  6$ dựa trên nhiều tiêu chí theo thứ tự ưu tiên. 

B. Thứ tự ưu tiên tiêu chí xếp hạng 

Trong trường hợp số Kill bằng nhau, cần xét đến các tiêu chí khác để xếp hạng người chơi, tránh trường hợp đồng hạng 

1. Kill (Số mạng hạ gục) 

• Tiêu chí chính để xác định thứ hạng. 

• Người có nhiều Kill hơn sẽ xếp trên. 

2. Death (Số lần bị hạ gục) 

• Nếu số Kill đều bằng nhau xét số Death. 

• Người có ít Death hơn sẽ được ưu tiên. 

3. Damage Dealt (Tổng sát thương gây ra) 

• Nếu số Kill và Death bằng nhau, so sánh tổng lượng Damage gây ra cho đối thủ. 

• Người gây nhiều sát thương hơn được ưu tiên xếp trên. 

Ví dụ: 

• A có 8 Kill, B có 6 Kill $ \mathsf { A }$ xếp trên B.   
• A và B đều có 7 Kill. A chết 2 lần, B chết 4 lần $ \mathsf { A }$ xếp trên B.   
• A và B đều có 6 Kill, 3 Death. A gây 12,000 Damage, B gây 10,000 Damage A xếp trên B 

3.3 Gold in match 

Nguồn Gold In Match 

Gold là nguồn tài nguyên nhận được trong trận dùng để nâng cấp chỉ số. Hết trận các chỉ số trả về 0 và Gold còn thừa trong trận sẽ không được giữ lại 

Có 2 nguồn để nhận Gold trong trận 

1. Gold hạ gục xe địch (Kill Gold) 

Người Kill nhận: 80 vàng.   
• Người chết: không mất vàng (tránh snowball). 

2. Gold ngẫu nhiên trong trận 

Spawn Rule: 

• Tỉ lệ xuất hiện: $5 0 \%$ Nhỏ, $3 5 \%$ Vừa, $1 5 \%$ Lớn.   
• Spawn interval: mỗi 15s   
• Không spawn trong 15s cuối   
• Vị trí spawn: Spawn ngẫu nhiên nhau map mỗi 10s trong vùng Safe Zone. Trong trường hợp Gold được spawn ra và chưa có ai 

Chi tiết: 

Random số lượng chest mỗi lần spawn 

Giai đoạn trận (Phase)

3.4 Edge Case 

• Respawn trong vùng đã bị co: Nếu điểm chết nằm ngoài Safe Zone $ { \mathsf { h } } { \hat { \mathsf { e } } }$ thống tự động chọn spawn point hợp lệ trong Safe Zone gần nhất. 

b. Giao tranh 

• Tank bắn và sử dụng skill như bình thường.   
Tank có thể nâng cấp chỉ số của mình thông qua hạt nâng cấp nhận được từ sentry. Đi vào thảm cỏ để ẩn mình.   
Dùng thảm teleport để dịch chuyển nhanh trên map. 

c. Sentry & nâng cấp 

Sentry được sắp đặt trước và rải rác trên map.   
Sentry bắn được tank.   
Sentry đứng gần nhau sẽ thành nhóm. 1 nhóm nhiều nhất là 2 sentries.   
Mỗi sentry chỉ thả 1 hạt năng lượng xuống đất.   
Sentry bị phá huỷ sẽ mọc lại sau 1 thời gian.   
Mỗi hạt năng lượng sẽ cho phép người chơi nâng 1 trong 4 chỉ số: HP, SPD, ATK, 

d. Event thời gian 

• Sau 30s, mìn sẽ thả xuống/mọc lên(?) xung quanh rìa của map (chiếm \~30% diện tích map) • Với mỗi 30s tiếp theo, mìn sẽ được thả nhiều hơn và sâu hơn vào giữa map. • Mìn giẫm lên sẽ gây 35% tổng HP của người chơi. 

-> Hạn chế vùng chơi sẽ bắt các người chơi còn lại giao tranh và kết thúc game. 

4. Art Requirement 

1. Concept - Art Concept cho cơ chế Co Map (Shrinking Arena) 

2. UI/UX 

A. Wireframe 

3. VFX/Animation 

4. Map Layout 

Balancing 

a. Gameflow mong muốn 

b. Kinh tế 

Scalability & Future Additions 

a. Bổ sung Môi trường & Sự kiện 

• Sự kiện ngẫu nhiên (RNG Events): 

◦ Thời tiết thay đổi (mưa, sấm sét, tuyết) ảnh hưởng tầm nhìn hoặc tốc độ di chuyển.   
◦ Quái xâm lược hoặc boss nhỏ xuất hiện, cho buff khi tiêu diệt. 

Địa hình động: 

◦ Thêm các loại địa hình gây ảnh hưởng gameplay như: làm chậm, trơn trượt, gây sát thương theo thời gian. ◦ Cỏ có thể biến mất tạm thời ở một số giai đoạn, tạo khoảng trống bắt buộc giao tranh. 

Vật phẩm đặc biệt: 

◦ Sinh ra “Divine Rapier” (vũ khí mạnh) tại giữa map sau X phút, tạo điểm tranh chấp.   
◦ Hộp tiếp tế ngẫu nhiên xuất hiện, chứa buff hoặc hạt nâng cấp. 

• Hệ thống Headhunt / Kill Spree: 

◦ Ghi nhận kill streak, thưởng tài nguyên hoặc buff cho người đang “on fire”.   
◦ Thêm cơ chế “bounty” ‒ càng sống lâu và giết nhiều, giá trị bị săn càng cao. 

Chế tạo vũ khí nâng cấp: 

◦ Giết địch hoặc phá sentry thu thập nguyên liệu, cho phép ghép thành một loại vũ khí/skill mạnh một lần trong trận. 

Mốc Thưởng (Milestone Buffs): 

◦ Đạt đủ số kill hoặc số nâng cấp nhất định để nhận buff tạm thời (tốc bắn, tốc chạy, hồi máu). 

c. Điều chỉnh Tương Tác Người Chơi 

Fog of War: 

◦ Giảm tầm nhìn hoặc thêm màn sương mờ dày dần khi map thu hẹp. 

d. Điều Chỉnh Kinh Tế Trận Đấu 

Farming Crates: 

Người chơi kiếm tài nguyên từ crate hoặc kill thay vì chỉ từ sentry, giúp đa dạng nguồn nâng cấp. 

• Cân bằng tần suất hạt năng lượng: 

◦ Điều chỉnh số lượng hạt rơi ra từ sentry, tank địch và event để tránh quá mạnh hoặc quá yếu.

Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) = R A N D B E T W E E N ( 1 , 4 )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $ N_{chest}(t) = RAND BETWEEN(1, 4) $ represents a randomization process used to determine the number of gold chests spawned at a given time $ t $. Here's a comprehensive analysis:

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation defines $ N_{chest}(t) $, the number of chests spawned at time $ t $, as a random integer uniformly distributed between 1 and 4 (inclusive). This introduces variability into the game mechanics, ensuring unpredictability and dynamic gameplay.

- **Variables and Definitions**:
  - $ N_{chest}(t) $: The number of gold chests spawned at time $ t $.
  - $ t $: A specific moment in time during the match when the spawn event occurs.
  - $ RAND BETWEEN(1, 4) $: A function that generates a random integer between 1 and 4, inclusive.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**: The equation employs the $ RAND BETWEEN(a, b) $ function, which is a discrete uniform random variable generator. This ensures equal probability for each outcome within the specified range.

- **Application Domain and Context**: The equation is part of the in-match gold generation system in a tank combat game. It governs the spawning of gold chests, which are critical for players to upgrade their tanks' attributes.

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: The randomness introduced by this equation prevents deterministic strategies, encouraging adaptability and strategic decision-making among players.

- **Relationship to Other Mathematical Concepts**: This equation is tied to probability theory, specifically discrete uniform distributions. It also interacts with other game systems, such as spawn intervals and phase-dependent chest values.

- **Practical Applications or Use Cases**: In-game resource management relies on this equation to balance fairness and engagement. By varying the number of chests, the game maintains excitement while controlling resource inflow.

- **Broader Discussion or Framework**: Within the broader context, this equation supports the dynamic economy of the game, influencing player progression and competitive balance. It aligns with the overall goal of creating an engaging and fair multiplayer experience.

These elements suggest that the table might detail variables such as gold distribution, spawn intervals, chest values, or upgrade costs.

### Table Structure and Organization:
Although the table's direct content is unavailable, its purpose seems to organize key parameters influencing gameplay mechanics, such as:
- **Gold Spawn Mechanics**: Randomized chest spawns with varying gold values depending on the phase of the match.
- **Upgrade Costs**: Weight Index (WIstat) and growth coefficients (StepGrowthstat) for upgrading tank stats like HP, SPD, ATK, etc.
- **Kill Gold Distribution**: Fixed rewards for kills (e.g., 80 gold per kill).

### Column Headers and Meanings:
The table likely includes columns such as:
1. **Phase**: Game phases (e.g., early, mid, late) affecting spawn rates and gold values.
2. **Nchest(t)**: Number of chests spawned at time `t`.
3. **Goldchest(t, j, Phase(t))**: Gold value of the `j`th chest during phase `t`.
4. **WIstat**: Weight index for stat upgrades.
5. **StepGrowthstat(k)**: Growth multiplier at upgrade level `k`.
These headers align with the detailed rules outlined in the surrounding text.

### Key Data Points and Patterns:
- **Gold Spawn Probabilities**: Chest sizes follow a distribution (50% small, 35% medium, 15% large), ensuring variability in rewards.
- **Spawn Interval**: Chests spawn every 15 seconds, except in the last 15 seconds of the match, maintaining urgency.
- **Safe Zone Dependency**: Spawn locations are tied to the shrinking Safe Zone, forcing players into contested areas.

### Statistical Insights and Trends:
- The diminishing spawn interval near the end of the match encourages aggressive play.
- Higher gold values in later phases incentivize survival and strategic positioning.
- Upgrade costs increase exponentially due to `StepGrowthstat`, balancing progression.

### Relationships Between Data Elements:
- **Gold and Progression**: Players must balance killing enemies (fixed 80 gold) versus collecting random chests (variable gold).
- **Upgrade Costs vs. Rewards**: Exponential growth in upgrade costs ensures that high-tier upgrades require significant resource accumulation.
- **Game Phases and Urgency**: Shrinking Safe Zones and increased mine density push players toward giao tranh (combat), accelerating the game's conclusion.

### Significance in Relation to Surrounding Context:
The table supports the game's core mechanics by defining parameters that govern fairness, progression, and tension. For instance:
- Fixed Kill Gold prevents snowballing advantages.
- Randomized chest spawns introduce unpredictability, rewarding exploration.
- Exponential upgrade costs prevent overpowered builds while encouraging strategic decision-making.

### Illustration of Concepts from Surrounding Content:
The table operationalizes concepts like 'Gold in Match' and 'Edge Cases' by quantifying abstract rules into concrete values. It also ties into sentry interactions and event-driven mechanics (e.g., mines reducing playable area), ensuring a cohesive gameplay experience.

Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
G o l d _ { s p a w n } ( t ) = \sum _ { j = 1 } ^ { N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) } G o l d _ { c h e s t } ( t , j , P h a s e ( t ) )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $ G o l d _ { s p a w n } ( t ) = \sum _ { j = 1 } ^ { N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) } G o l d _ { c h e s t } ( t , j , P h a s e ( t ) ) $ represents the total amount of Gold spawned at time $ t $ in a game environment. Here's a comprehensive analysis:

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation computes the total Gold available at a specific time $ t $ by summing the Gold values of all chests spawned at that moment. It is a discrete summation over the number of chests $ N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) $, where each chest contributes a Gold value $ G o l d _ { c h e s t } ( t , j , P h a s e ( t ) ) $.

- **Variables and Definitions**: 
  - $ G o l d _ { s p a w n } ( t ) $: Total Gold spawned at time $ t $.
  - $ N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) $: Number of chests spawned at time $ t $, determined randomly between 1 and 4.
  - $ G o l d _ { c h e s t } ( t , j , P h a s e ( t ) ) $: Gold value of the $ j $-th chest at time $ t $, which depends on the phase of the match.
  - $ P h a s e ( t ) $: Phase of the match at time $ t $, dividing the match into three stages.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**: The equation employs summation ($ \sum $) to aggregate Gold values from multiple chests. The random variable $ N _ { c h e s t } ( t ) $ introduces stochasticity into the model.

- **Application Domain and Context**: This equation is relevant to game mechanics, specifically in resource management systems. It models the dynamic generation of Gold, a critical resource for player progression.

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: The equation reflects the balance between randomness and structure in resource distribution, ensuring variability while maintaining fairness.

- **Relationship to Other Concepts**: It ties into broader game mechanics like spawn rules, Safe Zone dynamics, and upgrade costs, influencing player strategies.

- **Practical Applications**: In game design, this equation ensures controlled resource flow, preventing excessive accumulation or scarcity.

- **Relation to Broader Framework**: The equation supports the game's shrinking arena mechanic by incentivizing exploration and engagement within the Safe Zone.

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation, $ \gamma _ { O S t _ { s t a t } } ( k ) = B a s e C o s t \times W I _ { s t a t } \times S t e p G r o w t h _ { s t a t } (k) $, represents a cost function for upgrading attributes in a game context. Here's the detailed analysis:

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation calculates the cost of upgrading a specific attribute at the $k$-th step. It is a multiplicative model where the total cost depends on three factors: a fixed base cost ($BaseCost$), a weight index ($WI_{stat}$) that reflects the importance or rarity of the attribute, and a growth factor ($StepGrowth_{stat}(k)$) that scales with the upgrade level $k$. This implies an exponential or polynomial growth in cost as upgrades progress.

- **Variables and Definitions**:
  - $ \gamma _ { O S t _ { s t a t } } ( k ) $: Total cost of upgrading the attribute $stat$ at step $k$.
  - $BaseCost$: A constant representing the baseline cost for any upgrade.
  - $WI_{stat}$: Weight Index of the attribute $stat$, which encodes its relative importance or difficulty to upgrade.
  - $StepGrowth_{stat}(k)$: A function describing how the cost grows with each successive upgrade step $k$. This could follow a linear, exponential, or other progression depending on game design.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**: The equation uses multiplication to combine the base cost, weight index, and step growth. The function $StepGrowth_{stat}(k)$ likely involves a progression formula, such as $a \cdot b^k$ for exponential growth or $a + b \cdot k$ for linear growth.

- **Application Domain and Context**: This equation applies to a resource management system within a game. It governs how players spend their in-game currency (Gold) to enhance their characters' attributes (e.g., HP, SPD, ATK). The context suggests a balance between accessibility (low initial costs) and long-term engagement (increasing costs).

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: While not tied to physical phenomena, the equation models economic principles like diminishing returns and escalating investment requirements. It ensures that upgrades remain feasible early on but become progressively more challenging.

- **Relationship to Other Concepts**: The equation ties into the broader framework of in-game economies, particularly the Gold system described earlier. It interacts with spawn rules, kill rewards, and safe zones by influencing how players strategize resource allocation.

- **Practical Applications or Use Cases**: This formula can be implemented in game engines to dynamically calculate upgrade costs. Developers can adjust parameters ($BaseCost$, $WI_{stat}$, $StepGrowth_{stat}(k)$) to fine-tune gameplay balance.

- **Relation to Broader Discussion**: The equation supports the game’s competitive structure, encouraging players to prioritize upgrades strategically. It complements mechanisms like kill rewards, spawn intervals, and shrinking arenas by adding depth to decision-making.

[Game Mode Module] [Tank War] Gold in Match 

THÔNG TIN VÀNG TRONG TRẬN ĐẤU 

Ngày khởi tạo: 21 - 08 - 2025 

Người soạn: Q Kent 

Phiên bản mới nhất: v1.1 

1. Mục tiêu thiết kế 

• Trung tính ATK/DEF: Không để ATK hưởng lợi thế vàng tuyệt đối so với DEF. 

Chiến thuật rõ rệt: Người chơi không đủ vàng để max tất cả 40 cấp, buộc phải chọn build. 

• Nhịp độ hấp dẫn: Vàng tăng dần đều tới cuối trận, tạo cảm giác cao trào. 

• Không snowball gắt: Rubber-band nhẹ dựa trên Kill/Death để đội thua còn cơ hội. 

• Điều kiện thắng đặc biệt: Bên nào đạt 20 kills trước thắng ngay. 

2. Nguồn Gold trong trận 

2.1. Gold per Second (GpS) ‒ cho cả 2 phe 

• G_base $= 2$ vàng/giây. 

• Ramp multiplier (t giây): 

• Early ${ \sim } 1 . 0 \to \mathsf { M i d } \sim 1 . 1 8 \to \mathsf { E n d } \sim 1 . 3 5$ . 

• Rubber-band multiplier dựa trên Kill/Death: 

$\Delta K D = K D _ { t e a m } - K D _ { e n e m y } .$ Chuan hoa: $x = { \mathrm { c l a m p } } ( { \Delta K D } / { 6 } , - 1 , 1 ) ,$ He s6: 

Hieu luc 15s khi $| \Delta K D | \ge 6 ,$ sau d6 danh gia lai. 

Ky vong (khong rubber-band, van 240s): 

Kỳ vọng (không rubber-band, ván 240s): 

Tổng GpS/người ≈ 564 Gold 

2.2. Gold hạ gục xe địch (Kill Gold) 

• Người Kill nhận: 80 vàng.   
• Người chết: không mất vàng (tránh snowball).   
• Win condition: Bên nào đạt 20 mạng thắng ngay (dừng phát vàng tức thời).   
Kỳ vọng team thắng (20 kills): $\sim 1 6 0 0$ vàng tổng ${ \langle \approx } 3 2 0 ,$ /người, phân bố theo last-hit). 

2.3. Gold phá trụ (Objective Gold) 

• Phe ATK khi phá trụ: mỗi người $\mathbf { \Gamma } + \mathbf { 4 0 }$ vàng (tổng team = 200).   
• Phe DEF khi mất trụ: nhận $+ 1 0 \%$ GpS trong 15s (không cộng dồn, chỉ refresh). 

3. Chi phí nâng cấp (Upgrade Cost) 

3.1. Rule nâng cấp 

• Mỗi stat có 10 cấp (Level 1‒10).   
• Tổng cộng 40 cấp cho 4 stat (HP, Speed, FireRate, Damage).   
• Người chơi chỉ có thể đạt 12‒18 cấp/trận (không all-max). 

3.2. Công thức 

• HP: $\mathsf C = 5 0 , \mathsf g = 1 . 1 2 \mathsf C = 5 0 , \mathsf g = 1 . 1 2 \mathsf C = 5 0 , \mathsf g = 1 . 1 2$ • Speed: $\mathsf { C } = 4 0 , \mathsf { g } = 1 . 1 2 \mathsf { C } = 4 0$ , g=1.12C=40,g=1.12 • FireRate: $\mathtt { C } { = } 6 0$ ,g=1.15C $\mathtt { - 6 0 }$ , g=1.15C=60,g=1.15 • Damage: $\mathsf { C } = 7 0 , \mathsf { g } = 1 . 1 5 \mathsf { C } = 7 0$ , g=1.15C=70,g=1.15 

3.3. Bảng mẫu (vàng / cấp) 

Max 1 stat: HP $\sim 8 8 0$ vàng, Damage ${ \sim } 1 . 4 \mathbf { k }$ vàng $\Rightarrow$ không thể all-max. 

4. Sanity Check (1 trận 4’) 

• $\mathsf { G p S } \approx 5 6 4 / \mathsf { n g u } \mathsf { \dot { \alpha } i }$ .   
• Kill Gold (trung bình team thắng): \~320/người.   
• Tower Gold (ATK, 2 trụ): $+ 8 0$ /người. Tổng kỳ vọng/người: \~880‒960 vàng. 

Đủ để mua 12‒18 cấp, build đa dạng nhưng không full 40 cấp. 

5. Quy ước triển khai (dev-friendly) GpS mỗi giây: 

GpS = G_base \* (1 + rho\*(t/240)) \* M_rb 

Kill Event: 

On

Cost = FLOOR(C_s \* (g_s^(k-1)), 1) 

6. Nút tuning nhanh khi test 

• rho (độ dốc ramp): $0 . 3 0  0 . 4 0$ • KillerGold : $7 0  9 0$ • TowerGold_per_player : $3 5  4 5$ • kappa (KD gap): 5 ↔ 7 • rb_strength : 0.10 ↔ 0.15 • g_s (growth factor cost): $1 . 1 2  1 . 1 8$ 

7. Kết luận 

Với bản này, người chơi sẽ: 

• Luôn có vàng để bấm nâng liên tục (12‒18 cấp/trận).   
• Phải chọn đường nâng, không all-max.   
• Nhịp độ trận tăng đều tới cuối (GpS ramp).   
ATK/DEF cân bằng, có Rubber-band để chống snowball.

chunk-22d595c13bd6c383bc805cfd060b1bcc.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
G p S _ { p l a y e r } ( t ) = G _ { b a s e } \times M _ { \mathrm { r a m p } } ( t ) \times M _ { \mathrm { r b } } ^ { t e a m } ( t )
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $ G p S _ { p l a y e r } ( t ) = G _ { b a s e } \times M _ { \mathrm { r a m p } } ( t ) \times M _ { \mathrm { r b } } ^ { t e a m } ( t ) $ represents the calculation of Gold per Second ($ GpS $) for a player at time $ t $ in the context of a game mode described as 'Tank War.' This equation is central to balancing the in-game economy, ensuring fairness between Attack (ATK) and Defense (DEF) teams while maintaining an engaging pace.

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The function computes the instantaneous rate of gold accumulation for a player by multiplying three factors: $ G _ { b a s e } $, which is a constant base gold generation rate; $ M _ { \mathrm { r a m p } } ( t ) $, a time-dependent multiplier that increases gold generation over the course of the match; and $ M _ { \mathrm { r b } } ^ { t e a m } ( t ) $, a rubber-band multiplier that adjusts gold generation based on the team's performance relative to the enemy team.

- **Variables and Definitions**:
  - $ G _ { b a s e } $: Base gold generation rate, fixed at 2 gold/second.
  - $ M _ { \mathrm { r a m p } } ( t ) $: A ramp multiplier that evolves over time, starting at ~1.0 early in the match, increasing to ~1.18 mid-match, and reaching ~1.35 late in the match. This ensures escalating rewards as the game progresses.
  - $ M _ { \mathrm { r b } } ^ { t e a m } ( t ) $: A rubber-band multiplier derived from the normalized difference in Kill/Death ratios between the player's team and the enemy team ($ \Delta KD $). It prevents runaway advantages by dynamically adjusting gold generation to favor underperforming teams.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**: Multiplication is used to combine the base rate with the two multipliers. Additionally, the rubber-band multiplier involves normalization via clamping ($ x = \mathrm{clamp}(\Delta KD / 6, -1, 1) $), ensuring values remain within specified bounds.

- **Application Domain and Context**: This equation applies to real-time strategy games where resource management plays a critical role. By controlling gold generation rates, it influences decision-making around upgrades, combat strategies, and overall gameplay balance.

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: While not tied to physical phenomena, this equation models economic dynamics in competitive gaming scenarios. Its design reflects principles of game theory, particularly in incentivizing strategic choices without allowing one-sided dominance.

- **Relationship to Other Concepts**: The equation ties directly into other game mechanics such as upgrade costs, kill rewards, and objective-based bonuses. Together, these elements create a cohesive system that drives player engagement and maintains competitive equilibrium.

- **Practical Applications or Use Cases**: Developers can use this formula to fine-tune game difficulty and pacing, ensuring matches remain exciting and balanced. Players benefit indirectly through a more enjoyable and fair experience.

- **Relation to Broader Discussion/Framework**: This equation supports the stated goals of neutralizing ATK/DEF imbalance, encouraging tactical builds, and preventing excessive snowball effects. It contributes to the overarching framework of creating an immersive and strategically rich gaming environment.

chunk-fda7cab9f7f64af057fe67be89088e73.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
M _ { \mathrm { r a m p } } ( t ) = 1 + \rho \cdot \frac { t } { 2 4 0 } , \quad \rho = 0 . 3 5
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation $ M_{\text{ramp}}(t) = 1 + \rho \cdot \frac{t}{240} $, where $ \rho = 0.35 $, is a time-dependent multiplier function that governs the rate at which gold generation increases over the course of a match in the Tank War game mode. This equation is central to the design goal of creating an escalating sense of tension and progression as the match progresses. 

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation is a linear ramp function, where $ t $ represents the elapsed time in seconds (up to 240 seconds, the expected match duration). The term $ \frac{t}{240} $ normalizes the time variable to a value between 0 and 1, and $ \rho = 0.35 $ determines the maximum additional multiplier that can be achieved by the end of the match. The base multiplier starts at 1 (no increase) and grows linearly to $ 1 + \rho = 1.35 $ at $ t = 240 $. This ensures a gradual increase in gold generation over time.

- **Variables and Definitions**: 
  - $ M_{\text{ramp}}(t) $: The ramp multiplier at time $ t $, influencing the rate of gold generation.
  - $ t $: Time elapsed in seconds, bounded by the match duration (240 seconds).
  - $ \rho $: A constant parameter (0.35) that defines the slope of the ramp, controlling how steeply gold generation increases.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions**: The equation uses basic arithmetic operations (addition, multiplication, and division) to compute the multiplier. It is a piecewise-linear function with a domain of $ t \in [0, 240] $.

- **Application Domain and Context**: This equation is used in the context of balancing resource generation in a competitive multiplayer game. By gradually increasing gold generation, it ensures that players have more resources to spend on upgrades as the match progresses, aligning with the design goal of creating a high-stakes, climactic endgame.

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: The ramp function models a controlled escalation mechanism, preventing sudden spikes or plateaus in resource availability. This aligns with principles of game balance and player engagement, ensuring that matches remain dynamic and fair.

- **Relationship to Other Concepts**: The ramp multiplier works in conjunction with other gold-related mechanics, such as the base gold-per-second ($ G_{\text{base}} = 2 $), rubber-band multipliers based on kill-death ratios, and objective-based gold rewards. Together, these systems create a nuanced economy that supports strategic decision-making.

- **Practical Applications or Use Cases**: In practice, this equation ensures that gold generation scales smoothly, encouraging players to adapt their strategies as the match progresses. It also mitigates early-game advantages or disadvantages by providing a steady increase in resources.

- **Relation to Broader Discussion**: The equation is integral to the broader framework of balancing offense and defense, pacing the match, and maintaining player engagement. It reflects the designers' intent to create a balanced, strategic, and exciting gameplay experience.

chunk-5085eaf0c9b878e43824fb7cc56067cd.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
M _ { \mathrm { r b } } = \left\{ \begin{array} { l l } { 1 - 0 . 1 2 \cdot x , } & { x > 0 ( \mathrm { d a n g d \tilde { a } n } ) } \\ { 1 + 0 . 1 2 \cdot | x | , } & { x < 0 ( \mathrm { d a n g t h u a } ) } \\ { 1 , } & { x = 0 } \end{array} \right.
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation defines a piecewise function $ M_{\mathrm{rb}} $, which represents a 'rubber-band multiplier' used to adjust the rate of gold accumulation in the game mode based on the relative performance of a team. Here's a detailed breakdown:

1. **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: 
   The function $ M_{\mathrm{rb}} $ is designed to dynamically scale the gold-per-second (GpS) rate for each team based on their Kill/Death (KD) difference ($ \Delta KD $). This ensures that teams trailing behind receive a boost in gold generation, while leading teams experience a slight reduction. The variable $ x $ is derived from $ \Delta KD $ normalized by 6 and clamped between -1 and 1.

2. **Variables and Definitions**:
   - $ x $: A normalized value of $ \Delta KD $, representing the relative performance of a team compared to its opponent. Positive $ x $ indicates a leading team, negative $ x $ indicates a trailing team, and $ x = 0 $ indicates parity.
   - $ M_{\mathrm{rb}} $: The rubber-band multiplier applied to the base GpS rate to balance the game.

3. **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**:
   - Piecewise definition: The function uses conditional logic to apply different formulas depending on the sign of $ x $.
   - Linear scaling: For $ x > 0 $, the multiplier decreases linearly with a slope of -0.12. For $ x < 0 $, it increases linearly with a slope of +0.12.
   - Absolute value: Used to handle negative $ x $ values symmetrically.

4. **Application Domain and Context**:
   The equation is part of a game economy system designed to maintain competitive balance. By adjusting gold generation rates, it prevents runaway leads (snowballing) and keeps matches engaging until the end.

5. **Physical or Theoretical Significance**:
   The rubber-band mechanism introduces a form of dynamic difficulty adjustment, ensuring that no team gains an insurmountable advantage. This promotes strategic decision-making and rewards comebacks.

6. **Relationship to Other Mathematical Concepts**:
   - Normalization: $ x $ is normalized and clamped to ensure bounded input for the multiplier.
   - Game Theory: The equation aligns with principles of fairness and balance in competitive games.
   - Control Systems: The rubber-band effect resembles feedback control mechanisms, where outputs are adjusted based on deviations from a target state.

7. **Practical Applications or Use Cases**:
   - Balancing multiplayer games to enhance player satisfaction.
   - Preventing early-game advantages from determining outcomes, encouraging late-game strategies.

8. **Relation to Broader Discussion**:
   This equation is integral to the 'Gold per Second' system, ensuring that gold distribution remains fair and engaging throughout the match. It complements other systems like Kill Gold and Objective Gold, contributing to the overall design goals of neutrality, tactical depth, and pacing.

chunk-e749ace3b43c8425b3673633f55c9678.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
T \mathring { \circ } n g \ G p S / n g { \mathrm { u } \ o { \dot { \sigma } i } } \approx 5 6 4 \ v \dot { a } n g
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation, $ T \mathring { \circ } n g \ G p S / n g { \mathrm { u } \ o { \dot { \sigma } i } } \approx 5 6 4 \ v \dot { a } n g $, represents the total amount of Gold per Second (GpS) accumulated per player over the course of a match in the context of the Tank War game mode. Here is a detailed mathematical analysis:

1. **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation calculates the expected total gold earned per player over the duration of a match (240 seconds). It is derived from the base gold generation rate ($ G_{\text{base}} = 2 $) and incorporates multipliers such as the ramp multiplier and rubber-band mechanics.

2. **Variables and Definitions**:
   - $ G_{\text{base}} $: Base gold generation rate, fixed at 2 gold/second.
   - Ramp Multiplier: A time-dependent factor that increases from ~1.0 early in the game to ~1.35 by the end, simulating escalating tension.
   - Rubber-band Multiplier: Adjusts gold generation based on the Kill/Death differential ($ \Delta KD $), ensuring the losing team has a chance to recover.
   - $ T \mathring { \circ } n g \ G p S / n g { \mathrm { u } \ o { \dot { \sigma } i } } $: Total gold per second per player, approximated to 564 gold over 240 seconds.

3. **Mathematical Operations and Functions**:
   - Multiplication: Combines the base gold rate with multipliers.
   - Time Integration: Accumulates gold over the match duration (240 seconds).
   - Clamping: Limits the rubber-band effect to prevent extreme adjustments.

4. **Application Domain and Context**:
   - The equation applies to the economic system of the Tank War game mode, balancing resource distribution between teams.
   - It ensures neither team gains an overwhelming advantage, maintaining fairness and strategic depth.

5. **Physical or Theoretical Significance**:
   - The equation models a dynamic economic system where resources grow non-linearly over time.
   - It introduces controlled variability through rubber-band mechanics, enhancing gameplay balance.

6. **Relationship to Other Concepts**:
   - Linked to the Kill Gold and Objective Gold systems, which provide additional income sources.
   - Interacts with upgrade costs, influencing build strategies due to limited resources.

7. **Practical Applications or Use Cases**:
   - Balancing gameplay by preventing snowball effects.
   - Guiding players' decision-making regarding stat upgrades.
   - Informing designers about expected gold distributions for tuning game parameters.

8. **Broader Discussion Framework**:
   - This equation is central to the game's economy, supporting its design goals of neutral ATK/DEF dynamics, strategic depth, and engaging pacing.

chunk-1a92e05f61b0c23cef6ce47f933654c8.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
\begin{array} { r l } { \cdot } & { { } { \mathsf { H P } } { : } C = 5 0 , g = 1 . 1 2 } \\ { \cdot } & { { } { \mathsf { S p e e d } } { : } C = 4 0 , g = 1 . 1 2 } \\ { \cdot } & { { } { \mathsf { F i r e R a t e } } { : } C = 6 0 , g = 1 . 1 5 } \\ { \cdot } & { { } { \mathsf { D a m a g e } } { : } C = 7 0 , g = 1 . 1 5 } \end{array}
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The given equation defines the cost structure for upgrading four distinct player attributes (HP, Speed, FireRate, and Damage) in a game system. Each attribute follows an exponential growth model for its upgrade costs, characterized by two parameters: $ C $ (the base cost of the first level) and $ g $ (the growth factor applied multiplicatively to determine subsequent levels' costs). The mathematical form suggests that the cost of upgrading to level $ n $ is given by $ \text{Cost}(n) = C \cdot g^{n-1} $. This formula ensures escalating costs as players progress through levels, which aligns with balancing principles in gaming design to prevent rapid over-powering of characters.\n\nIn the context provided, these equations are crucial for resource management in the game. Players earn gold (GpS) over time or through specific events like kills and tower destruction, which they allocate toward attribute upgrades. The attributes have different base costs ($ C $) and growth factors ($ g $), reflecting their relative importance or balance in gameplay. For instance, Damage and FireRate have higher base costs and faster growth rates ($ g = 1.15 $) compared to HP and Speed ($ g = 1.12 $), suggesting that offensive capabilities are more expensive to develop but potentially more impactful.\n\nThe application domain is game design, where this equation helps establish a progression curve that maintains engagement by requiring strategic decision-making under resource constraints. It relates to broader concepts such as exponential growth, marginal utility, and optimization problems. Practically, it ensures diversity in playstyles since players cannot max out all attributes within a match due to limited resources (e.g., ~880‒960 gold per person per match). This fosters meaningful choices about prioritizing certain upgrades over others.\n\nThe equation ties into the overall framework by influencing how players interact with the economy (gold generation) and objectives (kills, towers). It also interacts with rubber-band mechanics, which adjust difficulty dynamically based on performance metrics like Kill/Death ratios.

chunk-b8ee7277f11b6cb8b2a9530f2a3ba4ad.content:
Mathematical Equation Analysis:
Equation: $$
C o s t _ { s } ( k ) = \lfloor C _ { s } \cdot g _ { s } ^ { ( k - 1 ) } floor
$$
Format: latex

Mathematical Analysis: The equation $ Cost_s(k) = \lfloor C_s \cdot g_s^{(k-1)} floor $ represents a cost function for upgrading a specific stat $ s $ to level $ k $. Here's a comprehensive analysis:

- **Mathematical Meaning and Interpretation**: The equation calculates the cost of upgrading a stat $ s $ to level $ k $ using a geometric progression. The base cost $ C_s $ is multiplied by a growth factor $ g_s $ raised to the power of $ (k-1) $, and the result is rounded down to the nearest integer using the floor function ($ \lfloor \cdot floor $).

- **Variables and Definitions**:
  - $ Cost_s(k) $: The cost of upgrading stat $ s $ to level $ k $.
  - $ C_s $: The base cost of upgrading stat $ s $.
  - $ g_s $: The growth multiplier for stat $ s $, determining how quickly the cost increases with each level.
  - $ k $: The target level of the stat $ s $ being upgraded.
  - $ \lfloor \cdot floor $: The floor function, ensuring that the cost is an integer value.

- **Mathematical Operations and Functions Used**: The equation involves multiplication, exponentiation, and the floor function. The geometric progression ensures exponential growth in upgrade costs as $ k $ increases.

- **Application Domain and Context**: This equation is part of a game economy system where players allocate resources (gold) to upgrade stats such as HP, Speed, FireRate, and Damage. The exponential growth in costs prevents players from maxing out all stats, encouraging strategic decisions.

- **Physical or Theoretical Significance**: The equation models diminishing returns in upgrades, a common mechanic in games to balance progression and resource management. It reflects real-world principles of exponential scaling, seen in areas like compound interest or population growth.

- **Relationship to Other Concepts**: The equation ties into the broader framework of resource allocation and progression systems. It interacts with other mechanics, such as Gold-per-Second (GpS) generation, Kill Gold, and Tower Gold, which provide players with the means to afford upgrades.

- **Practical Applications or Use Cases**: This formula ensures fairness and balance in gameplay by limiting the number of upgrades a player can achieve within a match. It also adds depth to decision-making, as players must prioritize which stats to upgrade based on their strategy.

- **Relation to Broader Discussion**: The equation supports the sanity check mentioned in the context, ensuring that players can afford approximately 12‒18 upgrades per match, aligning with the intended gameplay duration and resource availability.

[Game Mode Module] [Tank War] Outpost Breaker 

GAMEMODE OUTPOST BREAKER 

Phiên bản: v1.5 

Người tạo file: $\textcircled{9}$ Kent (QuocTA) 

Ngày cập nhật: 17 - 09 - 2025 

1. Mode Overview 

1.1 Mode Name: 

Capture Base (Chiếm Căn Cứ) 

1.2 Team Format: 

• 5v5 

1.3 Match Duration: 

• 4 minutes per match 

1.4 Map Setup: 

• 3 outpostbases positioned on the map • 2 teams set on the opposite sides of the map 

2. Victory Conditions 

2.1 Win Conditions: 

• Attacking Team (ATK): Wins if they capture all 3 outposts within 4 minutes. Defending Team (DEF): Wins if they retain at least 1 outpost until time runs out.   
• Either Team: Wins if they can kill 20 enemies first. 

2.2 Lose Conditions: 

• Attacking Team (ATK): Loses if they fail to capture all outposts within the time limit.   
• Defending Team (DEF): Loses if they lose control of all outposts before the match ends.   
• Either Team: Loses if the other team meets 20 kills first. 

3. Gameplay Flow 

• Players are assigned to ATK or DEF teams pre-match.   
• Outposts start under DEF control. ATK must coordinate and advance to capture outposts sequentially or simultaneously.   
• Once an outpost is captured by ATK, it cannot be retaken by DEF.   
• Gold generation systems are introduced to accelerate match pacing and reinforce comeback mechanics. 

4. Gold & Upgrade System 

4.1 Gold Earning Sources: 

• Enemy Tank Kill: Grants Gold for team.   
• Outpost Base Capture (ATK): Fixed Gold reward shared among all attackers.   
• Outpost Base Hold (DEF): Generates passive Gold per second per player while holding outpost. 

4.2 Balance Design Philosophy: 

• ATK Gold spikes with aggressive plays and coordinated captures. 

• Both sides can achieve power scaling via kill streaks and team strategy. 

• DEF Base close to outpost position 

• ATK Base far from outpost position 

4.3 Upgrade Shop: 

• Players spend Gold during matches to upgrade: 

◦ HP   
◦ Damage   
◦ Fire Rate   
◦ Movement Speed 

5. UI/UX & Map Design 

• Outpost Icons: Clearly marked A / B / C points on minimap, set position. 

• Capture Progress Icon: Each outpost shows real-time capture status. 

• Gold Counter: Visible for each player, shows earning rate and spend. 

• Skill Slot: A skill slot for each class for quick activation with cooldown visuals. 

• Upgrade Shop: Has 4 icons displaying side-by-side with gold value and stat value. 

6. Gold Balance 

6.1 Gold Sources In-Match (Calculate by Gold - g) 

6.2 Gold flow estimate (Summarized) 

7. Conclusion 

The "Capture Base" mode for Project TOG introduces a strategic tug-of-war between offense and defense. With asymmetric buffs and a resource-based upgrade system, it creates high-paced tactical gameplay, rewarding both coordination and moment-to-moment skill. 

8. Scalability & Future Additions 

• Map pools with different base layouts and terrain types.   
• Outpost-specific hazards (e.g., rotating turrets, flame walls).   
• Weather modifiers (fog, sandstorm) affect visibility.   
• Progression-based item unlock system.   
Weekly ranked mode with rotation between Capture Base and other PvP modes.   
• DEF teams can rebuild outposts by spending gold and time.

Footnotes: None Analysis: The table provides a structured breakdown of gold-earning mechanics in the 'Capture Base' game mode for Project TOG. The table consists of four columns: 'Event,' 'ATK Team,' 'DEF Team,' and 'Note.' Each row details specific events that generate gold for players, with distinctions between ATK (attackers) and DEF (defenders). 1. **Table Structure and Organization**: The table is organized into rows representing distinct in-game events and columns categorizing the rewards for ATK and DEF teams alongside additional notes. The first column lists the event type, while the second and third columns specify the gold rewards for each team. The fourth column provides clarifications or conditions for the rewards. 2. **Column Headers and Their Meanings**: - 'Event': Describes the action or condition triggering gold rewards (e.g., tank takedown, outpost capture). - 'ATK Team': Specifies the gold reward for the attacking team. - 'DEF Team': Specifies the gold reward for the defending team. - 'Note': Offers additional context or limitations for the rewards. 3. **Key Data Points and Patterns**: - Both teams earn equal gold (100g per person) for tank takedowns, promoting balanced incentives for combat engagement. - Outpost capture by ATK grants +300g per person per outpost, emphasizing the strategic importance of capturing outposts to accelerate ATK's resource accumulation. - Passive gold generation (+14g/s) is shared equally by both teams, ensuring a baseline income regardless of performance. - Kill streaks introduce dynamic bonuses: a streak of 3+ kills awards +50g, and ending a streak grants +100g to the player who breaks it, encouraging aggressive play and counter-play. 4. **Statistical Insights and Trends**: - ATK's ability to earn +300g per person per captured outpost creates significant gold spikes, aligning with the design philosophy of rewarding aggressive plays and coordinated captures. - The passive gold rate (+14g/s) ensures DEF can maintain economic stability even if they lose outposts, supporting their defensive strategy. - Streak mechanics provide opportunities for individual skill expression while discouraging excessive farming (non-stacking streak rewards). 5. **Relationships Between Data Elements**: - The table highlights the asymmetry between ATK and DEF gold sources: ATK benefits from high-reward outpost captures, while DEF relies on passive income and sustained defense. - Kill streak mechanics create inter-team competition, as ending streaks incentivizes teamwork and rewards counter-play. 6. **Significance of the Data in Relation to Surrounding Context**: - The table supports the 'Gold & Upgrade System' section by detailing how gold is distributed and earned during matches. - It reinforces the balance design philosophy by showing how ATK gains gold spikes through aggression, while DEF maintains steady income for resilience. - The data ties into the UI/UX design by providing metrics for the Gold Counter, which displays earning rates and spending options. 7. **How the Table Supports or Illustrates Concepts from Surrounding Content**: - The table illustrates the asymmetric buffs between ATK and DEF, such as ATK's exclusive outpost capture rewards versus DEF's passive gold generation. - It demonstrates the comeback mechanics mentioned in the surrounding content, as kill streak bonuses and streak-ending rewards allow underperforming players to regain momentum.

This progression reinforces the comeback mechanics and power scaling mentioned in the surrounding content. - The objectives shift from basic actions (kills and holds) to more complex, resource-intensive tasks (upgrades and final pushes), illustrating the escalating complexity of gameplay. - **Relationships Between Data Elements**: - The correlation between gold totals and objectives highlights how resource acquisition directly influences strategic capabilities. For instance, higher gold earnings at 3-4 minutes enable players to fully upgrade their stats, empowering them to execute decisive plays. - The asymmetry in objectives (e.g., ATK focusing on pushing while DEF aims for kills) reflects the mode's design philosophy of balancing offensive and defensive strategies. - **Significance of the Data in Relation to Surrounding Context**: - The table underscores the strategic tug-of-war described in the conclusion, where resource management and timing are critical for success. - It supports the concept of asymmetric buffs and pacing by showing how ATK and DEF teams have distinct paths to victory, leveraging gold spikes and sustained resource flows respectively. - **How the Table Supports Concepts from Surrounding Content**: - The table illustrates the balance design philosophy by demonstrating how ATK can capitalize on aggressive plays (e.g., capturing outposts) for gold spikes, while DEF benefits from passive gold generation via holding positions. - It complements the UI/UX design elements by providing context for the real-time gold counter and upgrade shop mechanics.

[Monetization Module] [Tank War] Economy & Monetization System 

HỆ THỐNG KINH TẾ VÀ PHƯƠNG THỨC KINH DOANH 

Phiên bản: v1.1 Người tạo file: Kent (QuocTA) Ngày tạo: 07 - 09 - 2025 

1. Currency Flow (Nguồn & Sink) 

1.1 Diamond (Hard Currency) 

1.2 Coin (Soft Currency) 

1.3 Battle Pass 

1.4 In-App Ads (Rewarded Ads) 

1.5 Shop In-Game 

2. Công thức Cơ bản (Draft) 

2.1 Phần thưởng trận (Match Reward Formula) 

CoinReward $=$ BaseReward $\times$ ModeMultiplier × (WinBonus/LoseFactor) $\times$ C S 

▪ BaseReward: 50 coin. 

▪ ModeMultiplier: • Deathmatch $= 1 . 0$ • Capture Base $= 1 . 2$ 

▪ WinBonus: x1.5. 

▪ LoseFactor: x1.0. 

▪ Combat Score: • $\mathsf { C S } = ( 0 . 5 \times [ ( \mathsf { K i l } | \mathsf { l } \mathsf { s } ) + ( 0 . 6 \times \mathsf { A s s i s t s } ) - ( 0 . 8 \times \mathsf { D e a t h s } ) ] ) + ( 0 . 4 \times \mathsf { D a m a g e 5 c o r e } )$ + (0.1 × Streak Bonus) 

Ví dụ minh họa 

Player thắng Capture Base. 

• Kills $= 5$ , Assists $= 4$ , Deaths $= 3 $ KDA Impact = 5 + (0.6×4) ‒ (0.8×3) = 5 + 2.4 ‒ $2 . 4 = 5 . 0$   
• Damage Score $= 1 . 1$ (trên trung bình role). Streak Bonus $= 1 . 0 5$ (Double Kill).   
• $\mathsf { C S } = ( 0 . 5 \times 5 . 0 ) + ( 0 . 4 \times 1 . 1 ) + ( 0 . 1 \times 1 . 0 5 ) = 2 . 5 + 0 . 4 4 + 0 . 1 0 5 = 3 . 0 4 5$ 

▪ CoinReward $= 5 0 \times 1 . 2 \times 1 . 5 \times 3 . 0 4 5 \approx 2 7 4$ coin (chỉ lấy số nguyên và sẽ làm tròn lén néu só thäp phän lón hon hoäc bäng 0.5,lam tron xuöng néu nhó hdn 0.5) 

2.2 Chi phí mở Tank 

Nguyên tắc thiết kế 

▪ F2P-friendly: tất cả Tank đều mở bằng Coin (soft currency). Tier-based progression: chi phí tăng theo Tier để khuyến khích người chơi gắn bó.   
▪ Class factor: mỗi Class (Scout, Assault, Heavy) có hệ số chi phí khác nhau phản ánh độ phức tạp & vai trò. 

▪ Time-to-Unlock: 

• Tank đầu tiên ngoài default $ \leqslant 3$ ngày chơi đều đặn.   
• Tank Tier $_ { 3 } \to$ khoảng 14 ngày.   
• Giữ động lực cho cả F2P và P2W. 

Công thức tính chi phí 

TankCost $\underline { { \underline { { \mathbf { \Pi } } } } }$ TierBase × ClassFactor

▪ Scout Tier $\pm  \mathord { \sim } 1 0$ trận. Assault Tier $2  \mathord { \sim } 1 8$ trận. Heavy Tier $\ 3  \sim 3 8$ trận. Heavy Tier $4  { \sim } 6 0$ trận.

2.3 Warp (Gacha) 

◦ Normal Warp (Coin): 

$N = \pm 0 0$ coin/lần Bảo hiểm (optional): 30 lần guaranteed Rare. 

◦ Premium Warp (Diamond):

2.4 Battle Pass Progression

• Seasonal cycle: mỗi Battle Pass (BP) kéo dài 6‒8 tuần (theo chu kỳ meta).

ần ▪ Bảo hiểm (optional): 50 lần guaranteed Epic, 90 lần Legendary. 

2.4 Battle Pass Progression 

Nguyên tắc thiết kế: 

• Seasonal cycle: mỗi Battle Pass (BP) kéo dài 6‒8 tuần (theo chu kỳ meta).   
• Dual track: Free track (Coin $^ +$ cosmetic cơ bản) & Paid track (Diamond-exclusive, Gen-AI ticket, premium cosmetic).   
• Match-driven: XP nhận chủ yếu qua chơi trận (Deathmatch, Capture Base).   
• Quest-driven: Daily/Weekly quest tăng tốc độ progression, chống nhàm chán. 

• Time-to-Complete: 

◦ Người chơi bình thường (\~10‒15 trận/ngày) hoàn thành $8 0 { - } 9 0 \%$ BP.   
◦ Người chơi hardcore/dùng boost hoàn thành $100 \%$ . 

Công thức tính XP 

BP_XP = MatchXP $\times$ ModeMultiplier × WinFactor 

MatchXP: 

▪ ModeMultiplier: 

• Deathmatch $= 1 . 0$ • Capture Base $= 1 . 2$ 

WinFactor: 1.2 khi thắng, 1.0 khi thua. 

▪ QuestBonus: • Daily Quest $= + 3 0$ XP (khoảng 2‒3 trận). • Weekly Quest $= + 1 5 0$ XP (khoảng 8‒10 trận). 

Level Progression (ước tính) 

• XP per Level $= 1 0 0$ XP.   
• Target Level: 50‒60 cấp / Season.   
• Completion Time: ◦ Casual: ${ \sim } 1 . 5 { - 2 }$ tuần để đạt lv30. ◦ Active: 5‒6 tuần đạt lv50 (max). 

Reward Distribution: 

• Free Track: ◦ Coin (đều đặn mỗi 5 lv). ◦ Warp thường (Coin-based gacha). 

◦ Decal thường.   
◦ Một số Artifact shard. 

• Paid Track: 

◦ Diamond (refund một phần phí BP).   
◦ Warp Premium (Diamond-based gacha).   
◦ Ticket Gen-AI (tạo Decal/Companion).   
◦ Decal Premium (Seasonal/LE).   
◦ Skin Premium (ở milestone cuối: lv50). 

Ví dụ milestone (Season length $5 0 \left. \mathbf { v } \right.$ ) 

Monetization Hooks 

• Paid Upgrade: 300‒500 Diamond/Season (\~5‒7 USD).   
• BP Boost: mua thêm “ $^ { 6 6 } + 1 0$ lv” hoặc $^ { 6 6 } { + } 1 0 0 0 \times \mathsf { P } ^ { 9 }$ ” bằng Diamond.   
• Engagement Loop: Paid track gắn Gen-AI & Skin để tạo động lực nạp. 

3. Guardrails (Chống Pay-to-Win) 

1. Tank Unlock 

Tất cả Tank có thể mua bằng Coin.   
▪ Thời gian mở tank đầu tiên $\leqslant 3$ ngày; tank meta $\leqslant 2$ tuần.

PvP Ranked: giới hạn Epic trở xuống.   
Legendary/Outstanding chỉ kích hoạt trong PvE/Event. 

3. Cosmetic Economy 

Warp/Decal/Skin không buff chỉ số. 

4. Ads vs Gameplay 

Giá trị $\mathsf { A d s } \leqslant 2 0 \%$ thu nhập Coin trung bình/ngày để tránh bypass gameplay.

The first column identifies the reward category, the second specifies its daily occurrence range, and the third explains its purpose or contextual significance. 2. **Column Headers and Their Meanings**: - 'Loai Reward': Specifies the type of reward distributed in the game (e.g., Ticket Gen-Al, Coin, Energy for Events, etc.). - 'Tan suat': Indicates how frequently these rewards are distributed daily, presented as a range (e.g., 1-2 times/day). - 'G': Provides additional context or purpose for each reward type, such as creating demand for AI Decal testing or limiting Free-to-Play (F2P) progression. 3. **Key Data Points and Patterns**: - **Ticket Gen-Al**: Distributed 1-2 times/day to create demand for AI Decal testing, suggesting this reward is tied to experimental or premium features. - **Coin**: Distributed 3-5 times/day, with a value approximating half of a winning match's reward, indicating it is a core soft currency reward mechanism. - **Năng lượng Event (LiveOps)**: Distributed once daily, linked to limited-time events, highlighting its role in driving engagement during special campaigns. - **Năng lượng PvE (Daily Dungeon)**: Distributed 1-2 times/day, designed to gate Free-to-Play (F2P) progression, ensuring balanced gameplay. 4. **Statistical Insights and Trends**: - Coins are the most frequently distributed reward, emphasizing their importance in the game's economy. - Limited-time event energy is the least frequent, aligning with its purpose of exclusivity and urgency. - The frequency ranges suggest a deliberate design to balance player engagement and resource scarcity. 5. **Relationships Between Data Elements**: - The frequency of rewards correlates with their purpose; higher-frequency rewards like coins serve as foundational incentives, while lower-frequency rewards like event energy target specific engagement goals. - The gating mechanism for F2P players through PvE energy ensures monetization opportunities for Pay-to-Win (P2W) players. 6. **Significance of the Data Presented**: - The table supports the surrounding content by detailing how different reward types contribute to the game's monetization strategy, particularly in balancing soft currency flow and incentivizing player participation in various activities. - It aligns with the earlier discussion on currency flow (Diamonds, Coins) and reward formulas, illustrating practical implementation. 7. **How the Table Supports Surrounding Content**: - The table complements the section on 'Currency Flow' by providing specific examples of how soft currency (Coins) and other resources (Energy) are distributed. - It reinforces the concept of 'Match Reward Formula' by showing how Coins are distributed multiple times daily, approximating fractional match rewards.

The structure is simple yet effective, consisting of three columns: 'Tier', 'BaseCost (Coin)', and 'Ghi chu' (Notes). The 'Tier' column categorizes tanks into four levels (Tier1 to Tier4), while the 'BaseCost (Coin)' column specifies the cost in coins required to unlock tanks at each tier. The 'Ghi chu' column provides contextual information about the purpose or significance of each tier. Key data points include the BaseCost values: Tier1 costs 2,000 coins, Tier2 costs 3,000 coins, Tier3 costs 5,000 coins, and Tier4 costs 8,000 coins. A clear pattern emerges where the cost increases significantly as the tier level rises, reflecting the game's design principle of encouraging player investment over time. This aligns with the surrounding content, which emphasizes a tier-based progression system that balances accessibility for free-to-play (F2P) users while incentivizing long-term engagement. Statistical insights reveal a non-linear increase in costs between tiers: the jump from Tier1 to Tier2 is 1,000 coins, Tier2 to Tier3 is 2,000 coins, and Tier3 to Tier4 is 3,000 coins. This exponential growth ensures that higher-tier tanks remain aspirational and reward sustained gameplay. The 'Ghi chu' column adds qualitative context, describing Tier1 tanks as beginner-friendly ('Xe nhäp món, dé tiep can'), Tier2 and Tier3 as progressively more advanced ('Meta co ban' and 'Meta nang cao'), and Tier4 as rare or late-game content ('Xe hiem/late progression'). Relationships between data elements are evident in how the BaseCost correlates with the tier's role in gameplay progression. Lower tiers are designed to be accessible early on, fostering initial engagement, while higher tiers serve as milestones for experienced players. This supports the surrounding content's emphasis on a 'Time-to-Unlock' framework, where Tier1 tanks are estimated to take ~10 matches to unlock, while Tier4 tanks require significantly more effort (~60 matches). The table's significance lies in its alignment with the broader monetization strategy outlined in the surrounding text. It illustrates the F2P-friendly approach by using soft currency (coins) for tank unlocks, ensuring inclusivity for all players. The table complements the discussion on match rewards and gameplay incentives, showing how earned coins contribute to unlocking progressively more valuable in-game assets.
